com.analog.lyric.dimple.model.domains

Class JointDomainIndexer

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.AbstractCollection<E>
      • java.util.AbstractList<D>
        • com.analog.lyric.dimple.model.domains.DomainList<DiscreteDomain>
          • com.analog.lyric.dimple.model.domains.JointDomainIndexer
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Iterable<DiscreteDomain>, java.util.Collection<DiscreteDomain>, java.util.List<DiscreteDomain>, java.util.RandomAccess
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    LargeJointDomainIndexer, StandardJointDomainIndexer

    @Immutable
public abstract class JointDomainIndexer
extends DomainList<DiscreteDomain>
    Provides a representation and canonical indexing operations for an ordered list of DiscreteDomain for use in implementing discrete factor tables and messages.

    Construct using one of the create methods listed below.

    The methods of this class employs the following terminology:

    size
    Refers to number of things in a single dimension: DomainList.size() is the number of domains in the indexer, getInputSize()/getOutputSize() are the number of domains that are designated as inputs/respectively. and getDomainSize(int) is the size of the nth domain.
    cardinality
    Is a combinatoric size across multiple dimensions: getCardinality() is the number of combinations of elements from all domains, and getInputCardinality()/getOutputCardinality() are the combinations involving only domains designated as inputs/outputs respectively.
    elements
    Refers to an array of elements of the domains in the indexer in their canonical order in the indexer, where the ith element is a member of the domain returned by DomainList.get(int)(i).
    indices
    Refers to an array of indices of domain elements in their canonical order in the indexer. This is an equivalent representation to elements but uses the element indexes rather than their actual values.
    values
    Refers to a Value array presumed to contain non-null DiscreteValues that contain both the element and index.
    joint index
    Is a single integral index representing a unique combination of indices/elements that maps each combination of values to the range [0, getCardinality()-1].
    domain index
    Refers to the index of a domain in the indexer considered as a DomainList, e.g. getInputDomainIndices() returns an array of indexes of domains designated as input domains.
    input index
    Is a single integral index representing a unique combination of just input indices/elements that maps each such combination to the range [0, getInputCardinality()-1]. Only meaningful for directed indexers.
    output index
    Is the same as input index but for outputs.

    See Also:
    create(DiscreteDomain...), DomainList.create(Domain...), create(BitSet, DiscreteDomain...), create(BitSet, JointDomainIndexer), create(int[], DiscreteDomain[]), DomainList.create(int[], Domain...), Serialized Form

      • allocateElements

        public final <T> T[] allocateElements(@Nullable
                       T[] elements)
        Returns an array with length at least DomainList.size() and with component type compatible with elements of all domains in list (i.e. a superclass of type specified by getElementClass().

        If elements fits the above description, it will simply be returned. If elements is too short but has a compatible component type, this will return a new array with length equal to DomainList.size() and component type the same as elements. Otherwise returns a new array with component type same as getElementClass().

      • allocateIndices

        public final int[] allocateIndices(@Nullable
                    int[] indices)
        Returns an array with length at least DomainList.size().

        If indices is non-null and is sufficiently long, it will be returned. Otherwise a newly allocated array will be returned.

      • getCardinality

        public abstract int getCardinality()
        The number of possible combinations of all domain elements. Equal to the product of all of the domain sizes.

        See Also:
        getInputCardinality(), getOutputCardinality()

      • getDomainSize

        public final int getDomainSize(int i)
        Returns the size of the ith domain in the list.

      • getElementClass

        public final java.lang.Class<?> getElementClass()
        Returns nearest common superclass for elements in all domains.

      • getIndicesComparator

        public java.util.Comparator<int[]> getIndicesComparator()
        Returns a comparator that orders indices arrays.

        If supportsJointIndexing(), this is guaranteed to produce the same order as the natural order of the corresponding joint indexes. If not isDirected() or hasCanonicalDomainOrder(), then the comparator implements a reverse lexicographical ordering (see Comparators.reverseLexicalIntArray()).

        The comparator is intended to be used with arrays of length DomainList.size().

      • getInputCardinality

        public int getInputCardinality()
        The number of possible combinations of input domain elements. Equal to the product of all of the input domain sizes. Will be one if not isDirected().
        See Also:
        getCardinality(), getOutputCardinality()

      • getInputDomainIndex

        public int getInputDomainIndex(int i)
        Returns the index of the ith domain designated as an input domain.

        This is equivalent to returning the ith element of getInputDomainIndices() but without having to allocate and copy an array.

        Throws:
        java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if i is not in range [0, getInputSize()-1] (will always throw if not isDirected().

      • getInputDomainIndices

        @Nullable
public int[] getInputDomainIndices()
        Returns a copy of the indexes of the input domains listed in increasing order or else null if not isDirected().

        Use getInputDomainIndex(int) to lookup an index without allocating a new array object.

      • getInputSet

        @Nullable
public java.util.BitSet getInputSet()
        /** Returns a copy of the BitSet representing the indexes of the input domains or else null if not isDirected().
        See Also:
        getInputDomainIndices(), getInputDomainIndex(int), getOutputSet()

      • getInputSize

        public int getInputSize()
        The number of input domains if isDirected(), otherwise zero.

        If directed, this must be greater than zero and when combined with getOutputSize() must add up to DomainList.size().

      • getOutputCardinality

        public abstract int getOutputCardinality()
        The number of possible combinations of output domain elements. Equal to the product of all of the output domain sizes. Will be the same as getCardinality() if not isDirected().
        See Also:
        getInputCardinality()

      • getOutputDomainIndex

        public int getOutputDomainIndex(int i)
        Returns the index of the ith output domain. If not isDirected() this treats all domains as output domains and will just return i if within range.
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if i is negative or not less than getOutputSize().

      • getOutputDomainIndices

        @Nullable
public int[] getOutputDomainIndices()
        Returns a copy of the indexes of the input domains listed in increasing order or else null if not isDirected().

        Use getOutputDomainIndex(int) to lookup an index without allocating a new array object.

        See Also:

      • getOutputSize

        public int getOutputSize()
        The number of output domains if isDirected(), otherwise the same as DomainList.size().

        If directed, this must be greater than zero and when combined with getInputSize() must add up to DomainList.size().

      • getStride

        public abstract int getStride(int i)
        Returns amount by which joint index returned by jointIndexFromIndices(int...) changes when ith element index changes by 1.

        This can be used to iterate over the joint indexes for one dimension for fixed values of all of the other dimensions.

        See Also:
        getUndirectedStride(int)

      • getUndirectedStride

        public abstract int getUndirectedStride(int i)
        Returns amount by which joint index returned by undirectedJointIndexFromIndices(int...) changes when ith element index changes by 1.

        This can be used to iterate over the joint indexes for one dimension for fixed values of all of the other dimensions.

        See Also:
        getStride(int)

      • isDirected

        public boolean isDirected()
        True if domain list is partitioned into inputs and outputs.

      • hasCanonicalDomainOrder

        public boolean hasCanonicalDomainOrder()
        True if not isDirected(). Otherwise, if isDirected(), then this is true if all the output domains in getOutputSet() are at the front of the list.

      • hasSameInputs

        public boolean hasSameInputs(int[] indices1,
                    int[] indices2)
        Returns true if two indices arrays have the same values at the indexes specified by getInputDomainIndices(). If not isDirected(), this will always return true.

      • inputIndexFromElements

        public int inputIndexFromElements(java.lang.Object... elements)
        Computes a unique index for the subset of elements designated as inputs.

        Similar to jointIndexFromElements(Object...) but computes value only from those elements indexed by getInputSet().

        Returns 0 if not isDirected().

        See Also:
        inputIndexFromIndices(int...), outputIndexFromElements(Object...)

      • inputIndexFromIndices

        public int inputIndexFromIndices(int... indices)
        Computes a unique index for the subset of indices designated as inputs.

        Similar to jointIndexFromIndices(int...) but computes value only from those element indices designated by getInputSet().

        Returns 0 if not isDirected().

        See Also:
        inputIndexFromElements(Object...), outputIndexFromIndices(int...)

      • inputIndexFromValues

        public int inputIndexFromValues(Value... values)
        Computes a unique index for the subset of values designated as inputs.

        Similar to jointIndexFromValues(Value...) but computes value only from those element indices designated by getInputSet().

        Returns 0 if not isDirected().

        See Also:
        inputIndexFromElements(Object...), inputIndexFromIndices(int...), outputIndexFromValues(Value...)

        public int inputIndexFromJointIndex(int jointIndex)
        Converts a joint index to an input index.

        Returns 0 if not isDirected().

        See Also:
        outputIndexFromJointIndex(int), jointIndexFromInputOutputIndices(int, int)

      • inputIndexToElements

        public void inputIndexToElements(int inputIndex,
                        java.lang.Object[] elements)
        Writes elements corresponding to inputIndex into corresponding elements array.

        Only updates members of elements designated as inputs, and therefore will do nothing if not isDirected().

        Parameters:
        inputIndex - must be in range [0, getInputCardinality()-1].
        elements - must have length equal to DomainList.size().

        See Also:
        inputIndexFromElements(Object...), outputIndexToElements(int, Object[])

      • inputIndexToValues

        public void inputIndexToValues(int inputIndex,
                      Value[] values)
        Writes elements corresponding to inputIndex into corresponding elements array.

        Only updates members of elements designated as inputs, and therefore will do nothing if not isDirected().

        Parameters:
        inputIndex - must be in range [0, getInputCardinality()-1].
        values - must have length equal to DomainList.size() and must be fully populated (i.e. no null entries) with Value objects with domain compatible with corresponding indexer domains.
        Since:
        0.07

      • inputIndexToIndices

        public void inputIndexToIndices(int inputIndex,
                       int[] indices)
        Writes element indices corresponding to inputIndex into corresponding indices array.

        Only updates members of indices for domains designated as inputs, and therefore will do nothing if not isDirected().

        Parameters:
        inputIndex - must be in range [0, getInputCardinality()-1].
        indices - must have length equal to DomainList.size().

        See Also:
        inputIndexFromIndices(int...), outputIndexToIndices(int, int[])

      • jointIndexFromElements

        public int jointIndexFromElements(java.lang.Object... elements)
        Computes a unique joint index associated with the specified domain elements.

        Parameters:
        elements - must have length equal to DomainList.size() and each elements must be an element of the corresponding domain.
        See Also:
        jointIndexFromIndices(int[]), jointIndexToElements(int, Object[])

      • jointIndexFromIndices

        public int jointIndexFromIndices(int... indices)
        Computes a unique joint index associated with the specified indices.

        The joint index is equivalent the inner product of the vector of stride values and indices. That is: 

               int jointIndex = 0;
       for (int i = 0; i < getDimensions(); ++i)
          jointIndex += getStride(i) * indices[i];

        Parameters:
        indices - must have length equal to DomainList.size() and each index must be a non-negative value less than the size of the corresponding domain otherwise the function could return an incorrect result.
        See Also:
        jointIndexFromElements(java.lang.Object...), jointIndexToIndices(int, int[]), validateIndices(int...)

      • jointIndexFromValues

        public int jointIndexFromValues(Value... values)

      • jointIndexFromInputOutputIndices

        public int jointIndexFromInputOutputIndices(int inputIndex,
                                   int outputIndex)
        Converts input and output indexes to a joint index.

        Returns outputIndex if not isDirected().

        Parameters:
        inputIndex - must be in range [0, getInputCardinality()-1]
        outputIndex - must be in range [0, getOutputCardinality()-1]

        See Also:
        inputIndexFromJointIndex(int), outputIndexFromJointIndex(int)

      • jointIndexToElements

        public <T> T[] jointIndexToElements(int jointIndex,
                           @Nullable
                           T[] elements)
        Computes domain values corresponding to given joint index.

        Parameters:
        jointIndex - a unique joint table index in the range [0,getCardinality()).
        elements - if this is an array of length DomainList.size(), the computed values will be placed in this array, otherwise a new array will be allocated.
        See Also:
        jointIndexToIndices(int, int[]), jointIndexFromElements(Object...)

      • jointIndexToValues

        public Value[] jointIndexToValues(int jointIndex,
                         Value[] values)
        Computes domain values corresponding to given joint index.

        Parameters:
        jointIndex - a unique joint table index in the range [0,getCardinality()).
        values - must have length equal to DomainList.size() and must be fully populated (i.e. no null entries) with Value objects with domain compatible with corresponding indexer domains.
        Since:
        0.07

      • jointIndexToElementIndex

        public int jointIndexToElementIndex(int jointIndex,
                           int domainIndex)
        Computes element index for a single domain from a joint index.

        This is like jointIndexToIndices(int, int[]) but only computes one element index.

        Parameters:
        jointIndex - must be in range [0, getCardinality()-1].
        domainIndex - must be in range [0, DomainList.size()-1].

        See Also:
        undirectedJointIndexToElementIndex(int, int)

      • jointIndexToIndices

        public int[] jointIndexToIndices(int jointIndex,
                        @Nullable
                        int[] indices)
        Computes domain indices corresponding to given joint index.

        Parameters:
        jointIndex - a unique joint table index in the range [0,getCardinality()).
        indices - if this is an array of length DomainList.size(), the computed values will be placed in this array, otherwise a new array will be allocated.
        See Also:
        jointIndexToElements(int, Object[]), jointIndexFromIndices(int...), jointIndexToElementIndex(int, int)

      • jointIndexToIndices

        public final int[] jointIndexToIndices(int jointIndex)
        Computes domain indices corresponding to given joint index.

        Same as jointIndexToIndices(int, int[]) with null second argument.

      • outputIndexFromElements

        public int outputIndexFromElements(java.lang.Object... elements)
        Computes a unique index for the subset of elements designated as outputs.

        Similar to jointIndexFromElements(Object...) but computes value only from those elements indexed by getOutputSet().

        Same as jointIndexFromElements(Object...) if not isDirected().

        See Also:
        outputIndexFromIndices(int...), inputIndexFromElements(Object...)

      • outputIndexFromIndices

        public int outputIndexFromIndices(int... indices)
        Computes a unique index for the subset of indices designated as outputs.

        Similar to jointIndexFromIndices(int...) but computes value only from those element indices designated by getOutputSet().

        Same as jointIndexFromIndices(int...) if not isDirected().

        See Also:
        outputIndexFromElements(Object...), inputIndexFromIndices(int...)

      • outputIndexFromValues

        public int outputIndexFromValues(Value... values)

      • outputIndexFromJointIndex

        public int outputIndexFromJointIndex(int jointIndex)
        Converts a joint index to an output index.

        Returns jointIndex if not isDirected().

        See Also:
        inputIndexFromJointIndex(int), jointIndexFromInputOutputIndices(int, int)

      • outputIndexToElements

        public void outputIndexToElements(int outputIndex,
                         java.lang.Object[] elements)
        Writes elements corresponding to outputIndex into corresponding elements array.

        Only updates members of elements designated as outputs, so this will only update all of the elements if not isDirected().

        Parameters:
        outputIndex - must be in range [0, getOutputCardinality()-1].
        elements - must have length equal to DomainList.size().

        See Also:
        outputIndexFromElements(Object...), inputIndexToElements(int, Object[])

      • outputIndexToValues

        public void outputIndexToValues(int outputIndex,
                       Value[] values)
        Writes elements corresponding to outputIndex into corresponding elements array.

        Only updates members of elements designated as outputs, so this will only update all of the elements if not isDirected().

        Parameters:
        outputIndex - must be in range [0, getOutputCardinality()-1].
        values - must have length equal to DomainList.size() and must be fully populated (i.e. no null entries) with Value objects with domain compatible with corresponding indexer domains.
        Since:
        0.07

      • outputIndexToIndices

        public void outputIndexToIndices(int outputIndex,
                        int[] indices)
        Writes element indices corresponding to outputIndex into corresponding indices array.

        Only updates members of indices for domains designated as inputs, and therefore will do nothing if not isDirected().

        Parameters:
        outputIndex - must be in range [0, getOutputCardinality()-1].
        indices - must have length equal to DomainList.size().

        See Also:
        outputIndexFromIndices(int...)

        Since:

      • undirectedJointIndexToElementIndex

        public abstract int undirectedJointIndexToElementIndex(int jointIndex,
                                     int domainIndex)
        Computes element index for a single domain from a joint index using undirected ordering of domains.

        This is like undirectedJointIndexToIndices(int, int[]) but only computes one element index.

        Parameters:
        jointIndex - must be in range [0, getCardinality()-1].
        domainIndex - must be in range [0, DomainList.size()-1].

        See Also:
        jointIndexToElementIndex(int, int)

      • undirectedJointIndexToIndices

        public abstract int[] undirectedJointIndexToIndices(int jointIndex,
                                  @Nullable
                                  int[] indices)

      • undirectedJointIndexToIndices

        public final int[] undirectedJointIndexToIndices(int jointIndex)

      • randomJointIndex

        public int randomJointIndex(java.util.Random rand)
        Generates a random joint index value in the range [0, getCardinality() - 1] using provided random number generator. Will throw an exception if not supportsJointIndexing().

        See Also:
        randomIndices(Random, int[])

      • randomIndices

        public int[] randomIndices(java.util.Random rand,
                  @Nullable
                  int[] indices)
        Generates a random set of indices for the domains using the supplied random number generator.
        Parameters:
        indices - if non-null and of length at least DomainList.size(), this indices will be written into this array. Otherwise a new one will be allocated.
        See Also:
        randomJointIndex(Random)

      • supportsJointIndexing

        public abstract boolean supportsJointIndexing()
        Indicates whether class supports operations involving single integer jointIndex representation. This will be false when the joint cardinality of the component domains is larger than 231.

      • supportsOutputIndexing

        public abstract boolean supportsOutputIndexing()
        Indicates whether class supports operations involving single integer output index representation of the subset of domains identified by getOutputSet(). This will be false when the joint cardinality of the component output domains is larger than 231. Note that this can be true when supportsJointIndexing() is false.

      • validateIndices

        public int[] validateIndices(int... indices)
        Verifies that the provided indices are in the correct range for this domain list, namely that:
        • indices has DomainList.size() elements
        • all values are non-negative
        • indices[i] < getDomainSize(int)(i)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if wrong number of indices
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if any index is out of range for its domain.

      • validateValues

        public Value[] validateValues(Value... values)

                        int[] inputIndices)
